title: Data Visualization: Mono Lake Water Levels from 1850 - 2017
description: This code wrangles data relating to Mono Lake water levels from 1850 to 2017.
contents:
hide

# Load in packages
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)
library(tidyverse)
library(here)
library(janitor)
library(GGally)
library(kableExtra)
library(modelsummary)
library(stargazer)
library(effsize)





hide

ggplot(data = mono_lake_clean, aes(x = year, y = lake_level_feet_above_sea_level)) + # Create line graph
  geom_line(color = "darkblue", 
            size = 0.4) + # Change color and size of lake level data
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(1850, 2020),
                     expand = c(0,0),
                     breaks = seq(1850, 2020, by = 25)) + # Fix x grid
  scale_y_continuous(limits = c(6372, 6428),
                     expand = c(0,0),
                     breaks = seq(6370, 6430, by = 10)) + # Fix y grid
  theme_minimal() + # Change theme 
  labs(x = "Year", # Add in plot labels
       y = "Water Level (Ft above Sea Level)",
       title = "Annual Mono Lake Water Levels: 1850 - 2017",
       caption = "Data: Mono Basin Clearinghouse") +
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size = 10, # Edit text 
                                    hjust = 0.5),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size = 10, 
                                    hjust = 0.5),
        plot.title = element_text(size = 14, 
                                  hjust = 0.5)) +
    geom_hline(yintercept = 6392, # Add in stable water level line
               linetype = "solid", 
               color = "darkgreen",
               size = 0.5) +
  geom_text(x = 1852, y = 6390, # Add in stable water level text
            label = "Stable Lake Level at 6,392 ft",
            color = "darkgreen",
            size = 3,
            hjust = 0,
            vjust = 0.5) +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 6377, # Add in Land Bridge line
             linetype = "dashed",
             color = "darkred",
             size = 0.5) +
  geom_text(x = 1852, y = 6375, 
            label = "Land Bridges Emerge at 6,377 ft", # Add in Land Bridge text
            color = "darkred",
            size = 3,
            hjust = 0,
            vjust = 0.5) +
  annotate("text", label = "1941: LA DWP Begins Diverting Water", # Add in historical event text
           x = 1950,
           y = 6420,
           size = 2.5,
           vjust = 0,
           hjust = 0.15) +
  geom_point(aes(x = 1941, y = 6417), # Add in point for historical event
             size = 1) +
  annotate("text", label = "1976: First Ecological Study", # Add in historical event text
           x = 1965,
           y = 6380,
           size = 2.5,
           vjust = .1,
           hjust = .8) +
  geom_point(aes(x = 1976, y = 6378), # Add in point for historical event
             size = 1) +
  annotate("text", label = "1998: State Issued Restoration Orders", # Add in historical event text
           x = 1995,
           y = 6388,
           size = 2.5,
           vjust = .2,
           hjust = .45) +
  geom_point(aes(x = 1998, y = 6384.4), # Add in point for historical event
             size = 1)




Figure 1: Mono Lake levels have plumented since 1941
in a 40 year time span due to the Los Angeles Department of Water &
Power (DWP) diverting water, causing the lake to los half its volume and
doubling in salinity. Once students discovered the ecological collapse
in 1976, action has been taken to decrease land bridges causing a
decline in bird nesting sites and to increase food resources for aquatic
birds.

title: Environmental Strategy Group Project
description: In this assignment, five MESM students were randomly assigned to a team to create an environmental strategy for a specific sustainability initiative. The team brainstormed an idea, researched the company and environmental problem, and wrote the complete report over four weeks. The assignment was completed purely for educational purposes for ESM 210: Business and the Environment.
contents:
In this assignment, five MESM students were randomly assigned to a
team to create an environmental strategy for a specific sustainability
initiative. The team brainstormed an idea, researched the company and
environmental problem, and wrote the complete report over four weeks.
The assignment was completed purely for educational purposes for ESM
210: Business and the Environment.
click
here for PDF of the report

title: Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering
description: This code will use hierarchical clustering by complete linkage to create a dendrogram showing multivariate clustering for water chemistry by site.
contents:
Overview
This code will use hierarchical clustering by complete linkage to
create a dendrogram showing multivariate clustering for water chemistry
by site. This data looks at Santa Barbara Coastal drainage are and has
been ongoing since 2000.
Variables
Total Dissolved Nitrogen uM
Total Dissolved Phosphorus uM
Total Particulate Carbon micromolesPerLiter
Total Particulate Nitrogen micromolesPerLiter
Total Suspended Solids (milligramPerLiter)
Data Citation: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and J.
Melack. 2019. SBC LTER: Land: Stream chemistry in the Santa Barbara
Coastal drainage area, ongoing since 2000 ver 16. Environmental Data
Initiative.


hide

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)

library(tidyverse)
library(janitor)
library(here)
library(naniar)
 
# Packages for cluster analysis:
library(NbClust)
library(cluster)
library(factoextra)
library(dendextend)
library(ggdendro)





hide

stream_chem <- read_csv( "sbc_lter_registered_stream_chemistry.csv")



Data Wrangling
To perform hierarchical clustering by site, I made a data frame that
has a single summary row per site (e.g.Â based on means from all
observations at that site). Then, I calculated the Euclidean distance
before performing complete linkage agglomerative hierarchical
clustering.


hide

stream_chem_clean <- stream_chem %>%
  na_if(-999) %>%
  clean_names() %>%
  group_by(site_code) %>%
  select(site_code, nh4_u_m:spec_cond_u_spercm) %>%
  summarize(
    "Ammonium" = mean(nh4_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Nitrate" = mean(no3_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Phosphorous" = mean(po4_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Dissolved Nitrogen" = mean(tdn_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Dissolved Phosphorous" = mean(tdp_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Particulate Carbon" = mean(tpc_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Particulate Nitrogen" = mean(tpn_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Particulate Phosphorous" = mean(tpp_u_m, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Suspended Solids" = mean(tss_mgper_liter, na.rm = TRUE),
    "Specific Conductivity" = mean(spec_cond_u_spercm, na.rm = TRUE))





hide

stream_chem_scale <- stream_chem_clean %>% 
  select(-site_code) %>%
  scale() # See ?scale for details on scaling

# compare scaled to original vars
summary(stream_chem_scale)


    Ammonium           Nitrate          Phosphorous       
 Min.   :-0.73964   Min.   :-0.77508   Min.   :-1.253113  
 1st Qu.:-0.43147   1st Qu.:-0.53141   1st Qu.:-0.840234  
 Median :-0.26219   Median :-0.38032   Median :-0.004647  
 Mean   : 0.00000   Mean   : 0.00000   Mean   : 0.000000  
 3rd Qu.: 0.08308   3rd Qu.: 0.01833   3rd Qu.: 0.344302  
 Max.   : 3.12885   Max.   : 2.69615   Max.   : 2.090693  
                                                          
 Dissolved Nitrogen Dissolved Phosphorous Particulate Carbon
 Min.   :-0.86299   Min.   :-1.146829     Min.   :-0.6849   
 1st Qu.:-0.40463   1st Qu.:-0.932105     1st Qu.:-0.5918   
 Median :-0.32968   Median : 0.009524     Median :-0.5082   
 Mean   : 0.00000   Mean   : 0.000000     Mean   : 0.0000   
 3rd Qu.:-0.02608   3rd Qu.: 0.417142     3rd Qu.: 0.5352   
 Max.   : 2.99465   Max.   : 2.215888     Max.   : 2.2479   
                                          NA's   :4         
 Particulate Nitrogen Particulate Phosphorous Suspended Solids  
 Min.   :-0.7090      Min.   :-0.61584        Min.   :-1.08381  
 1st Qu.:-0.6308      1st Qu.:-0.60567        1st Qu.:-0.87579  
 Median :-0.5227      Median :-0.56597        Median : 0.06448  
 Mean   : 0.0000      Mean   : 0.00000        Mean   : 0.00000  
 3rd Qu.: 0.5891      3rd Qu.:-0.02581        3rd Qu.: 0.37862  
 Max.   : 2.1037      Max.   : 2.20964        Max.   : 2.29779  
 NA's   :4            NA's   :4               NA's   :1         
 Specific Conductivity
 Min.   :-1.0191      
 1st Qu.:-0.6732      
 Median :-0.1254      
 Mean   : 0.0000      
 3rd Qu.: 0.2186      
 Max.   : 2.6730      
                      

Dendrogram
Complete Linkage


hide

rownames(stream_chem_scale) <- stream_chem_clean$site_code # adding rownames from original dataset



Figure 1: A cluster dendrogram that illustrates
water chemistry by site using complete linkage - the clusters are merged
by the smallest maximum distance between two
observations in distinct clusters. Data: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER
and J. Melack. (2019)


hide

stream_chem_dist <- dist(stream_chem_scale, method = 'euclidean') 

# Hierarchical clustering (complete linkage)
stream_hc_complete <- hclust(stream_chem_dist, method = "complete")


# Pretty plot
ggdendrogram(stream_hc_complete, 
             rotate = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Water Chemistry by Site (Complete Linkage)",
       x = "Stream Site",
       y = "Height",
       caption = "Data: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and J. Melack (2019).")




Single Linkage
Figure 2: Cluster dendrogram for illustrating water
chemistry by site using single linkage - the clusters are merged by the
smallest distance between observations in separate clusters.
Data: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and J. Melack. (2019)


hide

# Hierarchical clustering (single linkage)
stream_hc_single <- hclust(stream_chem_dist, method = "single")


# Pretty plot
ggdendrogram(stream_hc_single, 
             rotate = TRUE) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(title = "Water Chemistry by Site (Single Linkage)",
       x = "Stream Site",
       y = "Height",
       caption = "Data: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and J. Melack (2019).")




Results
There is a large mean concentration of Ammonium in stream 4
(DV01) which is the largest grouping
There are 3 sites in one of these two sub-groupings that all have
high Ammonium concentrations compared to other sites.
Since 9 out of 13 sites fit into one sub-grouping, this could
mean the variables are correlated in some way for most of the
sites.
All other sites are included in a grouping with at least two
sub-groupings.
Further investigation is needed for streams not included in the
larger sub-groups.
Citations
Data Citation: Santa Barbara Coastal LTER and J.
Melack. 2019. SBC LTER: Land: Stream chemistry in the Santa Barbara
Coastal drainage area, ongoing since 2000 ver 16. Environmental Data
Initiative.

title: Binary Logistic Regression Report
description: This code uses binary logistic regression to test the feasibility of using various variables to classify whether a palmetto is species Serenoa repens or Sabal etonia. For ESM 244.
contents:
Overview
This code uses binary logistic regression to test the feasibility of using variables plant height (height), canopy length (length), canopy width (width), and number of green leaves (green_lvs) to classify whether a palmetto is species Serenoa repens or Sabal etonia. Annual measures for Palmetto data included height, canopy length and width (all in cm), number of new and green leaves and flowering scapes. Data was collected continuously (not for all variables or sites) from 1981 through 1997 then again in 2001 and 2017. Data collection is ongoing at 5-year intervals.
Data source: Abrahamson, W.G. 2019. Survival, growth and biomass estimates of two dominant palmetto species of south-central Florida from 1981 - 2017, ongoing at 5-year intervals ver 1. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/f2f96ec76fbbd4b9db431c79a770c4d5


hide

knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE, message = FALSE, warning = FALSE)
library(purrr)
library(tidyverse)
library(Metrics)
library(cowplot)
library(here)
library(janitor)
library(broom)
library(ggbeeswarm)
library(stargazer)
library(kableExtra)
library(caret)





hide

# Read in the data
palmetto <- read_csv(here("data", "palmetto.csv"))



Data Wrangling


hide

palmetto_clean <- palmetto %>%
  select(species, height, length, width, green_lvs) %>%
  drop_na() %>% 
  mutate(species = case_when(species == "1" ~ "Serenoa repens",
                   species == "2" ~ "Sabal etonia"))



Data Exploration and Visualization


hide

ggplot(data = palmetto_clean, aes(x = height, y = width)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  facet_wrap(~ species) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("light blue", "dark blue")) +
  labs(x = "Plant Height (cm)",
       y = "Canopy Width (cm)",
       title = "Palmetto Height vs. Canopy Width (cm)",
       color = "Species")




Figure 1. Exploratory plot comparing the relationship between palmetto height (cm) and canopy width (cm) by species. Data: Abrahamson (2019).
For both palmetto species, plant height appears to increase with an increase in canopy width.


hide

ggplot(data = palmetto_clean, aes(x = green_lvs, y = height)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = species)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  facet_wrap(~ species) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("light blue", "dark blue")) +
  labs(x = "Green Leaf Count",
       y = "Plant Height (cm)",
       title = "Palmetto Height vs. Green Leaf Count",
       color = "Species")




Figure 2. Exploratory plot comparing the relationship between the number of green leaves observed and palmetto height (cm) for each species. Data: Abrahamson (2019).
The number of green leaves on a palmetto plant increases with an increase in plant height. The Sabal etonia species has a smaller range of 0 - 10 leaves. The Serenoa repens species has a greater range of number of green leaves, from 1 - 15 leaves.


hide

ggplot(data = palmetto_clean, aes(x = species, y = height)) +
  geom_jitter(aes(color = species,
                  alpha = 0.4)) +
  theme_minimal() +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("light blue", "dark blue")) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = NA, 
               width = 0.8) +
  stat_summary(fun=mean, 
               geom="point", 
               shape=18, 
               size=3, 
               color="black", 
               fill="black") +
  labs(x = "Palmetto Species",
       y = "Palmetto Height (cm)",
       title = "Palmetto Height (cm) vs Species") +
  theme(legend.position = "none")




Figure 3. Comparison between palmetto species Serenoa repens and Sabal etonia and the plant height (cm). The bolded black line indicates the median value and the black point within the box indicates the mean value for each species; the black points at either end of the vertical lines indicates outliers. Data: Abrahamson (2019).
Serenoa repens species has a slightly greater mean and median plant height, as well as a larger range, than that of the Sabal etonia species.
Binary Logistic Regression
Model 1


hide

palmetto_species <- palmetto_clean %>%
  drop_na() %>% 
  mutate(species = as.factor(species)) %>% 
  mutate(species = fct_drop(species))

# Code 1 (Serenoa repens) is the '0' level

# Check the levels

# levels(palmetto_species$species)

# Binary Logistic Regression
palmetto_blr1 <- glm(species ~ height + length + width + green_lvs, 
                            data = palmetto_species, 
                            family = "binomial")

# Look at the model
# palmetto_blr1


# summary(palmetto_blr1)

# Get a tidy version w/ broom: 
palmetto_blr1_tidy <- broom::tidy(palmetto_blr1)



Table 1. The results of the binary logistic regression model that predicts the probability of a palmetto plant being Sabal etonia or Serenoa repens, based off the predictor variables: plant height, canopy length, canopy width, and the number of green leaves. Coefficients, standard errors (in parentheses), and significance information are indicated for each predictor variable based on the dependent variable (Sabal etonia species). Data: Abrahamson (2019).


hide

stargazer(palmetto_blr1, type = "text",
          title = "Table 1: Binary Logistic Regression Results - Model 1",
          dep.var.labels = "Species: Sabal etonia",
          covariate.labels = c("Height", "Length", "Width", "Green leaf count"))



Table 1: Binary Logistic Regression Results - Model 1
=============================================
                      Dependent variable:    
                  ---------------------------
                     Species: Sabal etonia   
---------------------------------------------
Height                     0.029***          
                            (0.002)          
                                             
Length                     -0.046***         
                            (0.002)          
                                             
Width                      -0.039***         
                            (0.002)          
                                             
Green leaf count           1.908***          
                            (0.039)          
                                             
Constant                   -3.227***         
                            (0.142)          
                                             
---------------------------------------------
Observations                12,267           
Log Likelihood            -2,592.281         
Akaike Inf. Crit.          5,194.562         
=============================================
Note:             *p<0.1; **p<0.05; ***p<0.01

Model 2
Table 2: The results of the binary logistic regression model that predicts the probability of a palmetto plant being Sabal etonia or Serenoa repens, based off the predictor variables: plant height, canopy width, and the number of green leaves. Coefficients, standard errors (in parentheses), and significance information are indicated for each predictor variable based on the dependent variable (Sabal etonia species). Data: Abrahamson (2019).


hide

# Binary Logistic Regression
palmetto_blr2 <- glm(species ~ height + width + green_lvs, 
                            data = palmetto_species, 
                            family = "binomial")

# Look at the model
# palmetto_blr2

# summary(palmetto_blr2)

# Get a tidy version w/ broom: 
palmetto_blr2_tidy <- broom::tidy(palmetto_blr2)





hide

stargazer(palmetto_blr2, type = "text",
          title = "Table 2: Binary Logistic Regression Results - Model 2",
          dep.var.labels = "Species: Sabal etonia",
          covariate.labels = c("Height", "Width", "Green leaf count"))



Table 2: Binary Logistic Regression Results - Model 2
=============================================
                      Dependent variable:    
                  ---------------------------
                     Species: Sabal etonia   
---------------------------------------------
Height                       0.003           
                            (0.002)          
                                             
Width                      -0.069***         
                            (0.002)          
                                             
Green leaf count           1.885***          
                            (0.036)          
                                             
Constant                   -3.768***         
                            (0.135)          
                                             
---------------------------------------------
Observations                12,267           
Log Likelihood            -2,989.736         
Akaike Inf. Crit.          5,987.472         
=============================================
Note:             *p<0.1; **p<0.05; ***p<0.01

Results


hide

AIC <- AICcmodavg::aictab(list(palmetto_blr1, palmetto_blr2))



AICc for Model 1 (plant height, canopy length, canopy width and green leaves) is 5194.57
AICc for Model 2 (plant height, canopy width and green leaves) is 5987.48
Model 1 has a lower AIC value so we anticipate that model 1 will be the better model than model 2.


hide

# model 1
set.seed(100) 

tr_ctrl <- trainControl(method = "repeatedcv",
                        number = 10, repeats = 10)
 
# Train model 1
model1 <- train(species ~ height + length + width + green_lvs,
                data = palmetto_species,
                method = "glm", family = 'binomial',
                trControl = tr_ctrl)

 
# Train model 2
model2 <- train(species ~ height + width + green_lvs, data = palmetto_species,
               method = "glm", family = 'binomial',
               trControl = tr_ctrl)



Results: Model 1 predicts the species of Palmetto with 91.7 % accuracy. This is slightly greater than the 89.9 percent predictive accuracy of Model 2. The AIC value for Model 2 (5987.48) is greater than model 1 (5194.57). Given the more favorable AIC value and small reduction in predictive accuracy, this analysis will use Model 1.
Table 3: A table containing the number of palmetto plants in the original dataset correctly and incorrectly classified as their species by the binary logistic regression model. The percent correctly classified is displayed for each species. Data: Abrahamson (2019).


hide

# convert to probabilities

blr_fitted <- palmetto_blr1 %>% 
  augment(data = palmetto_species, type.predict = "response") %>% 
  mutate(predicted = ifelse(.fitted >= .5, "Serenoa repens", "Sabal etonia")) %>% 
  mutate(correct = ifelse(predicted == species, "predicted_correctly", "predicted_incorrectly"))

palmetto_table <- blr_fitted %>% 
  count(species, correct) %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = correct, values_from = n) %>% 
  mutate(total = rowSums(across(where(is.numeric)))) %>%
  mutate(percent = (predicted_correctly / total)* 100) %>%
  mutate_if(is.numeric,funs(as.character(signif(.,3))))

kableExtra::kable(palmetto_table,
                  col.names= c("Species", "Correct Prediction",
                               "Incorrect Prediction", "Total", "% Correct")) %>% 
    kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped",
                            full_width = F,
                            position ="center") %>% 
  kableExtra::add_header_above(bold = TRUE,
                               line = TRUE,
                               c("Percent species predicted correctly by binary logistic regression model 1" = 5))




Percent species predicted correctly by binary logistic regression model 1



Species


Correct Prediction


Incorrect Prediction


Total


% Correct


Sabal etonia


5700


454


6160


92.6


Serenoa repens


5550


564


6110


90.8


Model 1 (plant height, canopy length, canopy width and green leaves) is very effective at classifying a plant as either Sabal etonia (92.6%, n = 6160) and Serenoa repens (90.8%, n = 6110).
Data Citation
Data source: Abrahamson, W.G. 2019. Survival, growth and biomass estimates of two dominant palmetto species of south-central Florida from 1981 - 2017, ongoing at 5-year intervals ver 1. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/f2f96ec76fbbd4b9db431c79a770c4d5

title: Juvenile Snowshoe Hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest Report
description: This report provides an exploratory overview of the differences in juvenile Snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest. For ESM 206.
contents:
1. Overview
This report provides an exploratory overview of the differences in juvenile Snowshoe hares in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest through exploring annual hare trap counts between 1999 and 2012 and female and male juvenile hare weights in the following grids: Bonanza Riparian, Bonanza Mature, and Bonbs. This report also explores the relationship between juvenile hare weight and hind foot length. Bonanza Creek LTER is part of the US Long Term Ecological Research Network. The Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest (BCEF) was established in 1963 is a 50 km^2 experimental forest located approximately 20 km southwest of Fairbanks, Alaska (Kielland et al.Â 2017). Through data wrangling, data visualization, test sampling, summary statistics, and regression calculation, this report provides an exploratory analysis of juvenile Snowshoe hares.
2. Data and methods
Knut Kielland, Stuart F. Chapin, and Roger W. Ruess conducted capture-recapture studies of snowshoe hares at 5 locales in the Tanana Valley, from Tok in the east to Clear in the west from 1999 to 2012. The data contain observations for adult and juvenile Snowshoe hares (Lepus americanus) (Kielland et al.Â 2017). The initial investigation began with visualizing annual juvenile snowshoe hare traps to understand the population size, maximum and minimum counts, mean, and general trends. There is a general downwards trend in the number of juvenile hare trappings, especially between the years 2000 - 2001. This report also explores juvenile hare weights by sex and grid by finding the mean, standard deviation, and sample size. Weight between female and male hares was compared by two-sample t-tests using a significance level (\(\alpha\)) of 0.05. Linear regression explored the relationship between hare weight and hind foot length. All analyses are in R version 4.0.2 using RStudio version 1.3.1056.


hide

# Attach packages
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(tidyverse)
library(here)
library(janitor)
library(lubridate)
library(broom)
library(effsize)
library(broom)
library(kableExtra)
library(ggbeeswarm)



3. Preliminary results
A. Juvenile Snoeshow hare initial investigation


hide

# Read in data
bonanza_hares <- read_csv(here("data", "bonanza_hares.csv"))





hide

bonanza_hares_count <- bonanza_hares %>% # Clean and wrangle data
  filter (age == "j") %>%
  mutate(date_new = mdy(date)) %>%
  mutate(year = year(date_new)) %>%
  group_by(year) %>%
  count(year)

# Create graph
ggplot(data = bonanza_hares_count, aes(x = year, y = n)) +
  geom_col(color = "gray20",
           fill = "salmon1",
           stat = "identity",
           bins = 15) +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Year",
       y = "Number of Hare Traps") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(color = "gray20", face = "bold", hjust = 0.5),
        axis.title.x = element_text(color = "gray20", face = "bold"),
        axis.title.y = element_text(color = "gray20", face = "bold")) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = 1999:2012)




Figure 1: Count of annual juvenile hare traps from 1999 to 2002 at Bonanza Creek LTER from Kielland, K., et al, (2017).


hide

harecount_min <- min(bonanza_hares_count$n) # Find min

harecount_max <- max(bonanza_hares_count$n) # Find max

harecount_mean <- mean(bonanza_hares_count$n) # Find mean



The minimum counts of juvenile hare trappings is 2 and the maximum count is 126. The mean juvenile hare trappings count is 31.5. There is a general downwards trends in the number of juvenile hare trappings, especially between the years 2000 - 2001. No hares were trapped in 2002 and 2009. It would be recommended to standardize the trapping collection process to ensure accurate data.
B. Visualize juvenile Snowshoe hare weights


hide

# Clean and wrangle data
bonanza_hares_weights <- bonanza_hares %>%
  filter (age == "j") %>%
  mutate(sex_full = case_when(
    sex == "m" ~ "Male",
    sex == "f" ~ "Female",
    sex == "NA" ~ "Not Available")) %>%
  mutate(grid_full = case_when(
    grid == "bonrip" ~ "Bonanza Riparian",
    grid == "bonbs" ~ "Bonbs",
    grid == "bonmat" ~ "Bonanza Mature",
  )) %>%
  select(sex_full, weight, grid_full)

# Graph data
ggplot(data = bonanza_hares_weights, aes(x = sex_full, y = weight)) +
  geom_beeswarm(aes(color = sex_full), width = 3) +
  facet_grid(~ grid_full) +
  scale_color_manual(values = c("violetred", "cadetblue", "gray55")) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = NA, width = .3, outlier.color = NA) +
  stat_summary(fun = mean,
               geom = "point",
               shape = 18,
               size = 4,
               color = "black",
               fill = "black") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Hare Sex",
       y = "Hare Weight (g)",
       color = "Sex") +
   theme(axis.title.x = element_blank(),
        axis.title.y = element_text(face = "italic"))




Figure 2: Juvenile Snowshoe hare weights by sex at Bonanza Riparian, Bonanza Mature, and Bonbs in Bonanza Creek LTER from Kielland, K., et al, (2017).
Figure 2 is communicating how the sex of the hare and the location affects hare weights. From this visualization, it appears that sex does not have an impact on weights in juvenile hares since the means are similar for male and female hares. The visualization also shows that there is more data in the Bonanza Riparian grid vs the Bonbs grid, and that sex was not recorded for all data points.
C. Juvenile Snowshoe hare weight comparison
Table 1: Descriptive statistics (mean, standard deviation, and sample size) for juvenile hares by sex in Bonanza Creek LTER from Kielland, K., et al, (2017).


hide

# Clean data and pull in stats
bonanza_hares_weights_summary <- bonanza_hares_weights %>%
  group_by(sex_full) %>%
  summarize(mean_size = round(mean(weight, na.rm = TRUE), 1),
            median = round(median(weight, na.rm = TRUE), 2),
            standard_deviation = round(sd(weight, na.rm = TRUE), 1),
            sample_size = n()) 

# Create stats summary
kable(bonanza_hares_weights_summary, col.names = c("Sex", "Mean Size", "Median", "Standard Deviation", "Sample Size")) %>%
  kable_styling(bootstrap_options = c("striped", "hover", "condensed"), full_width = FALSE)

On average, juvenile male Snowshoe hares weigh more than juvenile female Snowshoe hares (945.86 \(\pm\) 333.22 and 855.39 \(\pm\) 292.25 g, respectively; mean \(\pm\) 1 standard deviation). While the absolute difference in means is 90.47 g (a 10.05% difference), the difference in means is significant (Welchâs two-sample t-test: t(325.02) = 2.71, p = 0.007), and the effect size is moderate (Cohenâs d = 0.29).
D. Relationship between juvenile Snowshoe hare weight and hind length


hide

# Clean data
bonanza_hares_hind <- bonanza_hares %>%
  filter (age == "j") %>%
  select(weight, hindft)

# Create graph
ggplot(data = bonanza_hares_hind, aes(x = weight, y = hindft)) +
  geom_point(color = "coral3", fill = "black", size = 2) + 
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", color = "gray40") +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(x = "Weight of Hares (g)",
       y = "Hind Foot Length (mm)") +
  theme(legend.position = c(0, 1600))



hide

# Do linear regression
bonanza_hares_hind_lm <- lm(weight ~ hindft, data = bonanza_hares_hind)


# Get tidy versions of the model output to call later on in text
bonanza_hares_hind_lm_tidy <- tidy(bonanza_hares_hind_lm)
bonanza_hares_lm_glance <- glance(bonanza_hares_hind_lm)

# See model diagnostics:
# plot(bonanza_hares_hind_lm)

# Get Pearson's r correlation
hares_cor <- cor.test(bonanza_hares_hind$weight, bonanza_hares_hind$hindft)

# Tidy version of correlation output:
hares_cor_tidy <- tidy(hares_cor)



Figure 3: The relationship between hind foot length (mm) and weight (g) for juvenile Snowshow hares at Bonanza Creek LTER. Linear model summary: \(\beta\)1 = 9.52 g mm-1, p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3, Pearsonâs r = 0.55). Data: Kielland et al.Â (2017).
The relationship between juvenile snowshoe hare weight and hind foot length initially seem linear (Figure 3). Simple linear regression reveals that juvenile Snowshoe hare hind foot length does not strongly predict juvenile snowshoe hare weight (p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3) with an average slope of \(\beta\) = 9.52 g mm-1 (i.e., for each millimeter increase in hind foot length we expect an average increase in weight of 9.52 g). Hind foot length and weight are moderately and positively correlated (Pearsonâs r = 0.55, p < 0.001). Diagnostic plots (not included) reveal normally distributed and homoscedastic residuals. I would suspect this model would require a logarithmic regression due to its shape, but further investigation is required.
4. Summary
Exploratory data analysis reveals the following initial findings:
The number of juvenile hares trapped between 1999 and 2012 has decreased significantly
Juvenile hares weight does not vary much between males and females
The most data was collected on the Bonanza Riparian grid for male and female juvenile hares
Juvenile hare weight vs hind foot length linear model summary: \(\beta\)1 = 9.52 g mm-1, p < 0.001, R2 = 0.3, Pearsonâs r = 0.55)
Next steps:
Complete multiple regression to fully understand the relationship between sex, weight, sampling site, and hind foot length.
Update sampling measures to ensure data is complete and accurate.
5. Citations
Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Snowshoe hare physical data in Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest: 1999-Present ver 22. Environmental Data Initiative. https://doi.org/10.6073/pasta/03dce4856d79b91557d8e6ce2cbcdc14 (Accessed 2021-11-07).
Kielland, K., F.S. Chapin, R.W. Ruess, and Bonanza Creek LTER. 2017. Study Sites & Design: Bonanza Creek Experimental Forest. Environmental Data Initiative. https://www.lter.uaf.edu/research/study-sites-bcef. (Accessed 2021-11-07).
